column1: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Iraq engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Iraq?

column6: Not close to perfect but getting better... https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jun/04/baghdads-green-zone-reopens-to-public-after-16-years

https://apnews.com/901565b549b54365a3a5df5a20c058dc Trump officials to Congress: Goal is deterring Iran, not war By LISA MASCARO and SUSANNAH GEORGE From <https://apnews.com/901565b549b54365a3a5df5a20c058dc> “We’re not about going to war,” Shanahan told reporters. “Our biggest focus at this point is to prevent Iranian miscalculation,” said Shanahan, flanked by Pompeo, after back-to-back briefings for the House and Senate. “We do not want the situation to escalate.” From <https://apnews.com/901565b549b54365a3a5df5a20c058dc>
Slight increase on previous forecast due to rising tensions with Iran which could cause problems between Iraq's Sunni and Shia population or between rival Shia groups.

Iraq has been the battle ground for the proxy and direct fighting between the US (on behalf of regional allies - KSA, Jordan, Isreal) and Iran. Iran has been meddling in the daily affairs of Iraq since before the 2003 Allied Invasion and has been propping up the minority Shiits and their militias. These militias were instrumental in forming the ISIL military (along with disgruntleted former Iraqi military officers who were cast aside during the reconstruction period). After the destruction of ISIL in Syria, thousands of ISIL fighters systematically dispersed back into the surrounding communities and countries to include Iraq and Jordan. (This also happened after the 2003 invasion where the fighters would disperse and blend with the small towns in Northern and Southern Iraq, making identification and rooting them out very difficult.
the region is highly unstable and there is a perceived lack of leadership in the country. it is a situation ripe for a strongman to step into the vacuum and attempt to take control
violance in Iraq is decreasing. last time 1000 people died in conflict was 2016. the 5% is due to us and iran tension
It is 15MAY19. The USA has just told its Embassy staff in The Green Zone to quit Iraq ASAP.
The armed groups target innocent civilian groups and this lead to fatalities especially after the rise of ISIS.

The number of civilian casualties has fallen massively since IS was effectively disbanded in Iraq. However, there remains extremist groups that may coalesce to pose a threat, especially if the US pulls out of Iraq. This is possibly the only plausible scenario which would result in the question being answered as a "Yes" but the chances of this happening appear to be very low within the given timeframe. The 2018 election seems to have brought a bit more stability to Iraq and should reduce the risk of Shia/Shia infighting. The appointment of a Kurdish president may also help to reduce Government/Kurdish tensions. There is likely to be continued unrest in the Sunni population in the south, especially if rebuilding in the ex-IS controlled towns is delayed. However, it is difficult to see a situation where this could result in 1,000 civilian deaths by 31 March 2020.
Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007
